SENT.plain: A 61-year-old male developed acute cerebellar swelling after thrombolytic therapy for basilar artery occlusion
He was treated with intra-arterial tissue plasminogen activator 12 hours following symptomatic onset, and did well in the immediate post-treatment period but deteriorated the next day
Computed tomography demonstrated acute cerebellar edema and hydrocephalus
Suboccipital external decompression and ventricular drainage were performed
He survived and 1 year later he could perform daily activities at home
Computed tomography and angiography are essential to monitor the post-treatment course following thrombolysis of vertebrobasilar occlusive disease
